00017 /**
00018     The size you should use when allocating strings for full paths.
00019     @ingroup files
00020 */
00021 #define MAX_PATH_CHARS      2048
00022 
00023 /**
00024     The size you should use when allocating strings for filenames.
00025     At the time of this writing it supports up to 256 UTF chars
00026     @ingroup files
00027 */
00028 #define MAX_FILENAME_CHARS  512
00029 
00030 
00031 typedef short FILE_REF;
00032 
00033 #define PATH_SEPARATOR_CHAR         '/'
00034 #define PATH_SEPARATOR_STRING       "/"
00035 #define PATH_CROSS_PLAT_NAMES
00036 #define SEPARATOR_CHAR              PATH_SEPARATOR_CHAR     // for backwards compatibility
00037 
00038 
00039 /**
00040     Constants that determine the output of path_nameconform().
00041     @ingroup files
00042     @see #e_max_path_types
00043     @see path_nameconform()
00044 */
00045 typedef enum {
00046     PATH_STYLE_MAX = 0,         ///< use PATH_STYLE_MAX_PLAT
00047     PATH_STYLE_NATIVE,          ///< use PATH_STYLE_NATIVE_PLAT
00048     PATH_STYLE_COLON,           ///< ':'  sep, "vol:"   volume, ":"   relative, "^:" boot
00049     PATH_STYLE_SLASH,           ///< '/'  sep, "vol:/"  volume, "./"  relative, "/"  boot
00050     PATH_STYLE_NATIVE_WIN       ///< '\\' sep, "vol:\\" volume, ".\\" relative, "\\" boot
00051 } e_max_path_styles;
00052 
00053 #ifdef WIN_VERSION 
00054 #define PATH_STYLE_MAX_PLAT         PATH_STYLE_SLASH
00055 #define PATH_STYLE_NATIVE_PLAT      PATH_STYLE_NATIVE_WIN
00056 #else
00057 #define PATH_STYLE_MAX_PLAT         PATH_STYLE_SLASH
00058 #define PATH_STYLE_NATIVE_PLAT      PATH_STYLE_SLASH    // PATH_STYLE_COLON path changes for Max 5-jkc
00059 #endif
00060 
00061 /**
00062     Constants that determine the output of path_nameconform().
00063     @ingroup files
00064     @see #e_max_path_styles
00065     @see path_nameconform()
00066 */
00067 typedef enum {
00068     PATH_TYPE_IGNORE = 0,       ///< ignore
00069     PATH_TYPE_ABSOLUTE,         ///< absolute path
00070     PATH_TYPE_RELATIVE,         ///< relative path
00071     PATH_TYPE_BOOT,             ///< boot path
00072     PATH_TYPE_C74,              ///< Cycling '74 folder
00073     PATH_TYPE_PATH              ///< path
00074 } e_max_path_types;
00075 
00076 
00077 #ifdef PATH_CROSS_PLAT_NAMES
00078 #define PATH_CHAR_IS_SEPARATOR(c) (((c) == ':') || ((c) == '/') || ((c) == '\\'))
00079 #else
00080 #define PATH_CHAR_IS_SEPARATOR(c) ((c) == PATH_SEPARATOR_CHAR)
00081 #endif
00082

00084 /**
00085     Flags used to represent properties of a file in a #t_fileinfo struct.
00086     @ingroup files
00087 */
00088 typedef enum {  
00089     PATH_FILEINFO_ALIAS = 1,    ///< alias
00090     PATH_FILEINFO_FOLDER = 2,   ///< folder
00091     PATH_FILEINFO_PACKAGE = 4   ///< package (Mac-only)
00092 } e_max_fileinfo_flags;
00093 
00094 #define FILEINFO_ALIAS      PATH_FILEINFO_ALIAS     // for backwards compatibility
00095 #define FILEINFO_FOLDER     PATH_FILEINFO_FOLDER    // for backwards compatibility
00096 
00097 
00098 /** Flags used by functions such as path_foldernextfile() and path_openfolder().
00099     @ingroup files
00100 */
00101 typedef enum {  
00102     PATH_REPORTPACKAGEASFOLDER = 1, ///< if not true, then a Mac OS package will be reported as a file rather than a folder.
00103     PATH_FOLDER_SNIFF = 2           ///< sniff
00104 } e_max_path_folder_flags;
00105 
00106 
00107 /**
00108     Permissions or mode with which to open a file.
00109     @ingroup files
00110 */
00111 typedef enum {  
00112     PATH_READ_PERM = 1,     ///< Read mode
00113     PATH_WRITE_PERM = 2,    ///< Write mode
00114     PATH_RW_PERM = 3        ///< Read/Write mode
00115 } e_max_openfile_permissions;
00116 #define READ_PERM       PATH_READ_PERM      // for backwards compatibility
00117 #define WRITE_PERM      PATH_WRITE_PERM     // for backwards compatibility
00118 #define RW_PERM         PATH_RW_PERM        // for backwards compatibility
00119

00122 // indices allow for fast access
00123 typedef enum {  
00124     PATH_STARTUP_PATH = 0,  
00125     PATH_SEARCH_PATH,   
00126     PATH_ACTION_PATH,
00127     PATH_HELP_PATH
00128 } e_max_path_indices;
00129 
00130 #define STARTUP_PATH    PATH_STARTUP_PATH       // for backwards compatibility
00131 #define SEARCH_PATH     PATH_SEARCH_PATH        // for backwards compatibility
00132 #define ACTION_PATH     PATH_ACTION_PATH        // for backwards compatibility
00133 #define HELP_PATH       PATH_HELP_PATH          // for backwards compatibility

00149 /**
00150     Information about a file.
00151     @ingroup files
00152 */
00153 typedef struct _fileinfo {
00154     long type;          ///< type (four-char-code)
00155     long creator;       ///< Mac-only creator (four-char-code)
00156     long date;          ///< date
00157     long flags;         ///< One of the values defined in #e_max_fileinfo_flags
00158 } t_fileinfo;
00159 
00160 
00161 /** The path data structure. This struct is provided for debugging convenience, 
00162     but should be considered opaque and is subject to change without notice. 
00163     @ingroup files
00164 */
00165 typedef struct _path {  
00166     void *p_name;       // all we have on Windows, may just be folder name on Mac   
00167     long p_dirID;       // directory ID on Mac  
00168     short p_vRefNum;    // volume on Mac    
00169     short p_wd;         // working directory on the Mac (compatibility mode)
00170 } t_path;
00171 
00172 
00173 /** The pathlink data structure. This struct is provided for debugging convenience, 
00174     but should be considered opaque and is subject to change without notice. 
00175     @ingroup files
00176 */
00177 typedef struct _pathlink {
00178     short l_path;       // index into path table, or p_wd in compatibility mode
00179     short l_ancestor;   // logical parent, i.e., what path caused this path to be included
00180     short l_temp;       // used for temporary flag when updating folders
00181     struct _pathlink *l_next;
00182     short l_parent;     // true parent folder
00183     short l_recursive;  // true if is or was added from a parent recursively
00184     void *l_watcher;    // watcher to see if this folder changes
00185 } t_pathlink;

00215 
00216 /**
00217     Find a Max document by name in the search path.
00218     This routine performs the same function as the routine path_getdefault().
00219     locatefile() searches through the directories specified by the user for 
00220     Patcher files and tables in the File Preferences dialog as well as the 
00221     current default path (see path_getdefault) and the directory
00222     containing the Max application
00223     
00224     @ingroup    files
00225     @param  name    A C string that is the name of the file to look for.
00226     @param  outvol  The Path ID containing the location of the file if it is found.
00227     @param  binflag If the file found is in binary format (it’s of type ‘maxb’) 1 is returned here; 
00228                     if it’s in text format, 0 is returned.
00229 
00230     @return         If a file is found with the name 
00231                     specified by filename, locatefile returns 0, otherwise it returns non-zero. 
00232     
00233     @remark         filename and vol can then be passed to binbuf_read to read and open file the file. 
00234                     When using MAXplay, the search path consists of all subdirectories of 
00235                     the directory containing the MAXplay application. locatefile only 
00236                     searches for files of type ‘maxb’ and ‘TEXT.’
00237     
00238     @see            locatefile_extended()
00239 */
00240 short locatefile(char *name, short *outvol, short *binflag);
00241 
00242 
00243 /**
00244     Find a Max document by name in the search path.
00245     This function searches through the same directories as locatefile, 
00246     but allows you to specify a type and creator of your own.
00247 
00248     @ingroup    files
00249     @param  name        A C string that is the name of the file to look for.
00250     @param  outvol      The Path ID containing the location of the file if it is found.
00251     @param  filetype    The filetype of the file to look for. 
00252                         If you pass 0L, files of all filetypes are considered.
00253     @param  creator     The creator of the file to look for. If you pass 0L, files with any creator are considered.
00254     
00255     @return         If a file is found with the name 
00256                     specified by filename, locatefile returns 0, otherwise it returns non-zero. 
00257 
00258     @see            locatefile_extended()
00259 */
00260 short locatefiletype(char *name, short *outvol, long filetype, long creator);
00261 
00262 short locatefilelist(char *name, short *outvol, long *outtype, long *filetypelist, short numtypes);
00263 
00264 
00265 /**
00266     Find a Max document by name in the search path.
00267     This is the preferred method for file searching since its introduction in Max version 4.
00268     
00269     This routine performs the same function as the routine path_getdefault().
00270     locatefile() searches through the directories specified by the user for 
00271     Patcher files and tables in the File Preferences dialog as well as the 
00272     current default path (see path_getdefault) and the directory
00273     containing the Max application
00274 
00275     @ingroup    files
00276     @version    4.0
00277     
00278     @param  name            The file name for the search, receives actual filename.
00279     @param  outvol          The Path ID of the file (if found).
00280     @param  outtype         The file type of the file (if found).
00281     @param  filetypelist    The file type(s) that you are searching for.
00282     @param  numtypes        The number of file types in the typelist array (1 if a single entry).
00283 
00284     @return         If a file is found with the name 
00285                     specified by filename, locatefile returns 0, otherwise it returns non-zero. 
00286 
00287     @remark         The old file search routines locatefile() and locatefiletype() 
00288                     are still supported in Max 4, but the use of a new routine 
00289                     locatefile_extended() is highly recommended. However, 
00290                     locatefile_extended() has an important difference from 
00291                     locatefile() and locatefiletype() that may require some rewriting 
00292                     of your code. <em>It modifies its name parameter</em> in certain cases, while 
00293                     locatefile() and locatefiletype() do not. The two cases where it 
00294                     could modify the incoming filename string are 1) when an alias is 
00295                     specified, the file pointed to by the alias is returned; and 2) when a full 
00296                     path is specified, the output is the filename plus the path number of the 
00297                     folder it's in. 
00298                     
00299                     This is important because many people pass the s_name field of a 
00300                     #t_symbol to locatefile(). If the name field of a #t_symbol were to be 
00301                     modified, the symbol table would be corrupted. To avoid this problem, 
00302                     use strncpy_zero() to copy the contents of a #t_symbol to a character string first, 
00303                     as shown below: 
00304     @code
00305     char filename[MAX_FILENAME_CHARS]; 
00306     strncpy_zero(filename,str->s_name, MAX_FILENAME_CHARS); 
00307     result = locatefile_extended(filename,&path,&type,typelist,1); 
00308     @endcode
00309 */
00310 short locatefile_extended(char *name, short *outvol, long *outtype, long *filetypelist, short numtypes);
00311 
00312 short locatefile_pathlist(t_pathlink *list, char *name, short *outvol, long *outtype, long *filetypelist, short numtypes);
00313 
00314 
00315 /**
00316     Resolve a Path ID plus a (possibly extended) file name 
00317     into a path that identifies the file’s directory and a filename.
00318     This routine converts a name and Path ID to a standard form in which 
00319     the name has no path information and does not refer to an aliased file. 
00320     
00321     @ingroup files
00322     @param  name    A file name (which may be fully or partially qualified), 
00323                     will contain the file name on return.
00324     @param  path    The Path ID to be resolved.
00325     @param  outpath The Path ID of the returned file name.
00326     
00327     @return         Returns 0 if successful.
00328 */
00329 short path_resolvefile(char *name, short path, short *outpath);
00330 
00331 
00332 /**
00333     Retrive a #t_fileinfo structure from a file/path combination. 
00334     
00335     @ingroup files
00336     @param  name    The file name to be queried.
00337     @param  path    The Path ID of the file.
00338     @param  info    The address of a #t_fileinfo structure to contain the file information.
00339     
00340     @return         Returns 0 if successful, otherwise it returns an OS-specific error code.
00341 */
00342 short path_fileinfo(char *name, short path, void *info);

00354 /**
00355     Create a fully qualified file name from a Path ID/file name combination.
00356     Unlike path_topotentialname(), this routine will only convert a 
00357     pathname pair to a valid path string if the path exists.
00358         
00359     @ingroup files
00360     @param  path    The path to be used.
00361     @param  file    The file name to be used.
00362     @param  name    Loaded with the fully extended file name on return.
00363     @return         Returns 0 if successful, otherwise it returns an OS-specific error code.    
00364 */
00365 short path_topathname(short path, char *file, char *name);
00366 
00367 
00368 /**
00369     Create a filename and Path ID combination from a fully qualified file name.
00370     Note that path_frompathname() does not require that the file actually exist. 
00371     In this way you can use it to convert a full path you may have received as an 
00372     argument to a file writing message to a form appropriate to provide to 
00373     a routine such as path_createfile().
00374         
00375     @ingroup files
00376     @param  name        The extended file path to be converted.
00377     @param  path        Contains the Path ID on return.
00378     @param  filename    Contains the file name on return.
00379     @return             Returns 0 if successful, otherwise it returns an OS-specific error code.    
00380 */
00381 short path_frompathname(char *name, short *path, char *filename);
00382 
00383 
00384 short path_frompotentialpathname(char *name, short *path, char *filename);
00385 
00386 
00387 void path_splitnames(const char *pathname, char *foldername, char *filename);
00388 short path_getnext(t_pathlink *list, short *val);
00389 
00390 
00391 /**
00392     Install a path as the default search path.
00393     The default path is searched before the Max search path. For instance, 
00394     when loading a patcher from a directory outside the search path, the 
00395     patcher’s directory is searched for files before the search path. 
00396     path_setdefault() allows you to set a path as the default.
00397 
00398     @ingroup files
00399     @param  path        The path to use as the search path.
00400                         If path is already part of the Max Search path, it will not be added 
00401                         (since, by default, it will be searched during file searches).
00402     @param  recursive   If non-zero, all subdirectories will be installed in the default search list.
00403                         Be very careful with the use of the recursive argument—it has the capacity to 
00404                         slow down file searches dramatically as the list of folders is being built. 
00405                         Max itself never creates a hierarchical default search path.
00406 */
00407 void path_setdefault(short path, short recursive);
00408 
00409 
00410 /**
00411     Retrieve the Path ID of the default search path. 
00412     @ingroup files
00413     @return The path id of the default search path.
00414 */
00415 short path_getdefault(void);

00454 /**
00455     Prepare a directory for iteration.
00456     @ingroup files
00457     @param  path    The directory Path ID to open.
00458     @return         The return value of this routine is an internal “folder state” structure 
00459                     used for further folder manipulation. It should be saved and used for 
00460                     calls to path_foldernextfile() and path_closefolder(). 
00461                     If the folder cannot be found or accessed, path_openfolder() returns 0.
00462 */
00463 void *path_openfolder(short path);
00464 
00465 
00466 /**
00467     Get the next file in the directory.
00468     In conjunction with path_openfolder() and path_closefolder(), 
00469     this routine allows you to iterate through all of the files in a path.
00470 
00471     @ingroup files
00472     @param  xx          The “folder state” value returned by path_openfolder().
00473     @param  filetype    Contains the file type of the file type on return.
00474     @param  name        Contains the file name of the next file on return.
00475     @param  descend     Unused.
00476     @return             Returns 0 if successful, and an error code if unsuccessful. 
00477     @see                #e_max_path_folder_flags
00478 */
00479 short path_foldernextfile(void *xx, long *filetype, char *name, short descend);
00480 
00481 
00482 /**
00483     Complete a directory iteration.
00484     @ingroup files
00485     @param  x   The “folder state” value originally returned by path_openfolder().
00486 */
00487 void path_closefolder(void *x);

00572 
00573 /**
00574     Present the user with the standard open file dialog.
00575     This function is convenient wrapper for using Mac OS Navigation 
00576     Services or Standard File for opening files. 
00577 
00578     The mapping of extensions to types is configured in the C74:/init/max-fileformats.txt file.
00579     The standard types to use for Max files are ‘maxb’ for old-format binary files, 
00580     ‘TEXT’ for text files, and 'JSON' for newer format patchers or other .json files.
00581 
00582     @ingroup files
00583     @param  name    A C-string that will receive the name of the file the user wants to open.
00584                     The C-string should be allocated with a size of at least #MAX_FILENAME_CHARS.
00585     @param  volptr  Receives the Path ID of the file the user wants to open.
00586     @param  typeptr The file type of the file the user wants to open.
00587     @param  types   A list of file types to display. This is not limited to 4 
00588                     types as in the SFGetFile() trap. Pass NULL to display all types.
00589     @param  ntypes  The number of file types in typelist. Pass 0 to display all types.
00590     
00591     @return         0 if the user clicked Open in the dialog box.  
00592                     If the user cancelled, open_dialog() returns a non-zero value.
00593     
00594     @see saveasdialog_extended()
00595     @see locatefile_extended()
00596 */
00597 short open_dialog(char *name, short *volptr, long *typeptr, long *types, short ntypes);
00598 
00599 
00600 // TODO: Not documenting this right now -- this prototype differs from the documentation (taken from WEOFM)
00601 /*
00602     Present the user with the standard save file dialog.
00603     This function is convenient wrapper for using Mac OS Navigation 
00604     Services or Standard File for saving files. 
00605 
00606     The mapping of extensions to types is configured in the C74:/init/max-fileformats.txt file.
00607     The standard types to use for Max files are ‘maxb’ for old-format binary files, 
00608     ‘TEXT’ for text files, and 'JSON' for newer format patchers or other .json files.
00609 
00610     @ingroup files
00611     @param  filename    A C-string containing a default name for the file to save.
00612                         If the user decides to save a file, its name is returned here.
00613                         The C-string should be allocated with a size of at least #MAX_FILENAME_CHARS.
00614 
00615     @param  path        If the user decides to save the file, the Path ID of the location chosen is returned here.
00616 
00617     @param  format      The default Max file format for saving the file. If 
00618                         format is set to 2, the Normal binary mode will be 
00619                         selected. If format is 0, Text will be selected. When 
00620                         the user decides to save the file, the choice of file 
00621                         format is returned here. If you pass 0L for format 
00622                         instead of a pointer to a short, the choice for saving the 
00623                         file in binary or text formats is not presented to the 
00624                         user. This is appropriate when you always save your 
00625                         object’s files in a specialized format. format 1 was used 
00626                         in previous version of Max to save in "Old Format",which is no longer supported.
00627     
00628     @return             0 if the user choose to save the file.  
00629                         If the user cancelled, returns a non-zero value.
00630     
00631     @see open_dialog()
00632     @see saveasdialog_extended()
00633     @see locatefile_extended()
00634 */
00635 short saveas_dialog(char *name, short *volptr, short *binptr);
00636 
00637 
00638 /**
00639     Present the user with the standard save file dialog with your own list of file types.
00640     This function is convenient wrapper for using Mac OS Navigation 
00641     Services or Standard File for saving files. 
00642 
00643     saveasdialog_extended() is similar to saveas_dialog(), but allows the 
00644     additional feature of specifying a list of possible types. These will be 
00645     displayed in a pop-up menu. 
00646     
00647     File types found in the typelist argument that match known Max types 
00648     will be displayed with descriptive text. Unmatched types will simply 
00649     display the type name (for example, "foXx" is not a standard type so it 
00650     would be shown in the pop-up menu as foXx) 
00651     
00652     Known file types include:
00653     - TEXT: text file 
00654     - maxb: Max binary patcher 
00655     - maxc: Max collective 
00656     - Midi: MIDI file 
00657     - Sd2f: Sound Designer II audio file 
00658     - NxTS: NeXT/Sun audio file 
00659     - WAVE: WAVE audio file. 
00660     - AIFF: AIFF audio file
00661     - mP3f: Max preference file 
00662     - PICT: PICT graphic file 
00663     - MooV: Quicktime movie file 
00664     - aPcs: VST plug-in 
00665     - AFxP: VST effect patch data file 
00666     - AFxB: VST effect bank data file 
00667     - DATA: Raw data audio file 
00668     - ULAW: NeXT/Sun audio file
00669 
00670     @ingroup files
00671     @param  name        A C-string containing a default name for the file to save.
00672                         If the user decides to save a file, its name is returned here.
00673                         The C-string should be allocated with a size of at least #MAX_FILENAME_CHARS.
00674 
00675     @param  vol         If the user decides to save the file, the Path ID of the location chosen is returned here.
00676 
00677     @param  type        Returns the type of file chosen by the user.
00678     @param  typelist    The list of types provided to the user. 
00679     @param  numtypes    The number of file types in typelist.
00680     
00681     @return             0 if the user choose to save the file.  
00682                         If the user cancelled, returns a non-zero value.
00683     
00684     @see open_dialog()
00685     @see locatefile_extended()
00686 */
00687 short saveasdialog_extended(char *name, short *vol, long *type, long *typelist, short numtypes);
00688 
00689 void saveas_autoextension(char way);
00690 void saveas_setselectedtype(long type);
00691 
00692 void typelist_make(long *types, long include, short *numtypes);

00697 short preferences_subpath(char *name, short path, short create, short *subpath);
00698 short textpreferences_read(char *filename, short path, short defaultid);
00699 short textpreferences_default(short id);
00700 void *textpreferences_open(void);
00701 void textpreferences_addraw(void *p, char *fmt, ...);
00702 void textpreferences_add(void *p, char *fmt, ...);
00703 void textpreferences_addoption(void *p, char *fmt, ...);
00704 void textpreferences_addrect(void *p, char *msg, short top, short left, short bottom, short right);
00705 short textpreferences_close(void *p, char *filename, short path);
